title: How to Make a Garden Swing

steps.headline: Cut your pieces using a circular saw.
steps.description: You will need five 21-inch (53.34-centimeter) long boards for the support joists. You will also need two 72-inch (182.88-centimeter) long boards for the front and back aprons. Lastly, you will need five 18⅛-inch (46.038-centimeter) long boards for the back supports Each board needs to be 4 inches (10.16 centimeters) wide and 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) thick.

steps.headline: Attach the support joists to the front apron.
steps.description: They need to be 15⅝ inches (39.69-centimeters) apart. Make sure that the first and last support joists are flush with the edges of the front apron. Drill 1½-inch (3.81-centimeter) pocket holes first, then insert 2½-inch (6.35-centimeter) pocket hole screws. You will need two pocket holes on each end of each board. Both the jousts and the apron should be standing up on their sides.

steps.headline: Attach the back apron to the tops of the support joists.
steps.description: When you are done, you should have a rectangle with three vertical bars running through it. Use 2½-inch (6.35-centimeter) screws and wood glue. Drill the holes first, then coat both pieces of wood with wood glue. Clamp the boards together, then insert the screws.

steps.headline: Add the back supports.
steps.description: Attach them to the back apron. They need to be 13⅝ inches (34.61 centimeters) apart. Use 2½-inch (6.35-centimeter) screws and wood glue.

parts.name: Adding the Arm Rests and Slats

steps.headline: Cut your pieces.
steps.description: You will need two 11¼-inch (28.58-centimeter) long boards for the arm fronts. You will also need two 25½-inch (64.77-centimeter) long boards for the arm rests. Each board needs to be 4 inches (10.16 centimeters) wide and 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) thick.

steps.headline: Attach the arm fronts to the front apron.
steps.description: Attach each arm front to the each end of the front apron. Make sure that the bottom edge of each arm front is aligned with the bottom edge of the apron. Once again, use 2½-inch (6.35-centimeter) screws and wood glue.

steps.headline: Secure the arm rests on top.
steps.description: Make sure that the back end of the arm rest is level with the front end. Use a level to make sure that the arm rests are flat. Secure them with 2½-inch (6.35-centimeter) screws and wood glue.

steps.headline: Cut the slats.
steps.description: You will need six boards that at 72 inches (182.88 centimeters) long. Each board needs to be 6 inches (15.24 centimeters) wide and 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) thick.

steps.headline: Attach two slats to the back rest.
steps.description: Position the slats above and below the arm rests. The top of the bottom slat should be flush with the bottom of the arm rest. Use 2-inch (5.08-centimeter) finish nails and wood glue.

steps.headline: Add the seat slats.
steps.description: Attach the remaining four slats to the support joists. Leave ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) gaps between them. The first slat should be flush to the arm fronts. The back slat should be flush to the back supports. Use 2-inch (5.08-centimeter) finish nails and wood glue.

steps.headline: Smooth out the surface of the wood, if needed.
steps.description: Fill in any holes using wood filler. Let the filler dry, then sand it smooth with 120 grit sandpaper—be sure that you sand with the wood grain, not against it. Wipe away any dust using a damp cloth. If you will be painting your swing, it would be a good idea to apply some primer.

steps.headline: Paint or stain the swing.
steps.description: If you wish to preserve the natural texture of the wood, apply a wood stain. If you wish to give it a solid color, paint it with a durable, outdoor quality paint. Apply the paint or stain according to the directions on the can, as each product will be a little different. You may need more than one coat of paint. Be sure to let the previous coat dry before applying the next one.

steps.headline: Seal the swing.
steps.description: Choose a waterproof, outdoor quality varnish. Apply three coats to your swing. Allow each coat to dry before applying the next one. Whether you use a matte, satin, or glossy finish is entirely up to you. Sealing is important, even if the paint you use is labeled as waterproof.

steps.headline: Attach eye bolts to sides of support jousts, right between the arm front and back rest.
steps.description: Drill the hole first, all the way through the joust. Place a washer over the hole, then a nut. Twist in the eye bolt, all the way through the board. Place another washer over the end of the bolt on the other side of the beam. Lastly, twist on the nut. Make sure that the looped part of the bolt is oriented vertically. When you look at the swing straight on from the front, it should be shaped like a "O".

steps.headline: Feed the rope through both hooks and tie.
steps.description: Cut two long pieces of study rope. Feed your first rope through both hooks on the left side. Feed your second rope through both hooks on the right side. Tie the ends together into a sturdy knot on each side. The rope needs to have a 200-pound (90.72-kilo) weight capacity.

steps.headline: Attach the swing to a sturdy branch or rafter.
steps.description: Make sure that whatever you are hanging the swing from can support the weight. If you are hanging the swing from a set of rafters, use eye screws or heavy duty swing hangers. If the swing is still too tippy after you hang it, add one more set of eye bolts and ropes  to the backrest. For more comfort, hang it at a slight backward angle, about five degrees.

tyn: Six 1 by 6-inch (2.54 by 15.24-centimeter) wooden boards, 6 feet (1.83 meters) long
Five 2 by 4-inch (5.08 by 10.16-centimeter) wooden boards, 8 feet (2.44 meters) long
Four 3-inch (7.62-centimeter) long eye bolts and nuts
text: Making the Base Cut your pieces using a circular saw. You will need five 21-inch (53.34-centimeter) long boards for the support joists. You will also need two 72-inch (182.88-centimeter) long boards for the front and back aprons. Lastly, you will need five 18⅛-inch (46.038-centimeter) long boards for the back supports Each board needs to be 4 inches (10.16 centimeters) wide and 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) thick. Attach the support joists to the front apron. They need to be 15⅝ inches (39.69-centimeters) apart. Make sure that the first and last support joists are flush with the edges of the front apron. Drill 1½-inch (3.81-centimeter) pocket holes first, then insert 2½-inch (6.35-centimeter) pocket hole screws. You will need two pocket holes on each end of each board. Both the jousts and the apron should be standing up on their sides. Attach the back apron to the tops of the support joists. When you are done, you should have a rectangle with three vertical bars running through it. Use 2½-inch (6.35-centimeter) screws and wood glue. Drill the holes first, then coat both pieces of wood with wood glue. Clamp the boards together, then insert the screws. Add the back supports. Attach them to the back apron. They need to be 13⅝ inches (34.61 centimeters) apart. Use 2½-inch (6.35-centimeter) screws and wood glue. Adding the Arm Rests and Slats Cut your pieces. You will need two 11¼-inch (28.58-centimeter) long boards for the arm fronts. You will also need two 25½-inch (64.77-centimeter) long boards for the arm rests. Each board needs to be 4 inches (10.16 centimeters) wide and 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) thick. Attach the arm fronts to the front apron. Attach each arm front to the each end of the front apron. Make sure that the bottom edge of each arm front is aligned with the bottom edge of the apron. Once again, use 2½-inch (6.35-centimeter) screws and wood glue. Secure the arm rests on top. Make sure that the back end of the arm rest is level with the front end. Use a level to make sure that the arm rests are flat. Secure them with 2½-inch (6.35-centimeter) screws and wood glue. Cut the slats. You will need six boards that at 72 inches (182.88 centimeters) long. Each board needs to be 6 inches (15.24 centimeters) wide and 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) thick. Attach two slats to the back rest. Position the slats above and below the arm rests. The top of the bottom slat should be flush with the bottom of the arm rest. Use 2-inch (5.08-centimeter) finish nails and wood glue. Add the seat slats. Attach the remaining four slats to the support joists. Leave ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) gaps between them. The first slat should be flush to the arm fronts. The back slat should be flush to the back supports. Use 2-inch (5.08-centimeter) finish nails and wood glue. Painting and Hanging the Swing Smooth out the surface of the wood, if needed. Fill in any holes using wood filler. Let the filler dry, then sand it smooth with 120 grit sandpaper—be sure that you sand with the wood grain, not against it. Wipe away any dust using a damp cloth. If you will be painting your swing, it would be a good idea to apply some primer. Paint or stain the swing. If you wish to preserve the natural texture of the wood, apply a wood stain. If you wish to give it a solid color, paint it with a durable, outdoor quality paint. Apply the paint or stain according to the directions on the can, as each product will be a little different. You may need more than one coat of paint. Be sure to let the previous coat dry before applying the next one. Seal the swing. Choose a waterproof, outdoor quality varnish. Apply three coats to your swing. Allow each coat to dry before applying the next one. Whether you use a matte, satin, or glossy finish is entirely up to you. Sealing is important, even if the paint you use is labeled as waterproof. Attach eye bolts to sides of support jousts, right between the arm front and back rest. Drill the hole first, all the way through the joust. Place a washer over the hole, then a nut. Twist in the eye bolt, all the way through the board. Place another washer over the end of the bolt on the other side of the beam. Lastly, twist on the nut. Make sure that the looped part of the bolt is oriented vertically. When you look at the swing straight on from the front, it should be shaped like a "O". Feed the rope through both hooks and tie. Cut two long pieces of study rope. Feed your first rope through both hooks on the left side. Feed your second rope through both hooks on the right side. Tie the ends together into a sturdy knot on each side. The rope needs to have a 200-pound (90.72-kilo) weight capacity. Attach the swing to a sturdy branch or rafter. Make sure that whatever you are hanging the swing from can support the weight. If you are hanging the swing from a set of rafters, use eye screws or heavy duty swing hangers. If the swing is still too tippy after you hang it, add one more set of eye bolts and ropes  to the backrest. For more comfort, hang it at a slight backward angle, about five degrees.
sentences: Making the Base Cut your pieces using a circular saw.
You will need five 21-inch (53.34-centimeter) long boards for the support joists.
You will also need two 72-inch (182.88-centimeter) long boards for the front and back aprons.
Lastly, you will need five 18⅛-inch (46.038-centimeter) long boards for the back supports Each board needs to be 4 inches (10.16 centimeters) wide and 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) thick.
Attach the support joists to the front apron.
They need to be 15⅝ inches (39.69-centimeters) apart.
Make sure that the first and last support joists are flush with the edges of the front apron.
Drill 1½-inch (3.81-centimeter) pocket holes first, then insert 2½-inch (6.35-centimeter) pocket hole screws.
You will need two pocket holes on each end of each board.
Both the jousts and the apron should be standing up on their sides.
Attach the back apron to the tops of the support joists.
When you are done, you should have a rectangle with three vertical bars running through it.
Use 2½-inch (6.35-centimeter) screws and wood glue.
Drill the holes first, then coat both pieces of wood with wood glue.
Clamp the boards together, then insert the screws.
Add the back supports.
Attach them to the back apron.
They need to be 13⅝ inches (34.61 centimeters) apart.
Use 2½-inch (6.35-centimeter) screws and wood glue.
Adding the Arm Rests and Slats Cut your pieces.
You will need two 11¼-inch (28.58-centimeter) long boards for the arm fronts.
You will also need two 25½-inch (64.77-centimeter) long boards for the arm rests.
Each board needs to be 4 inches (10.16 centimeters) wide and 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) thick.
Attach the arm fronts to the front apron.
Attach each arm front to the each end of the front apron.
Make sure that the bottom edge of each arm front is aligned with the bottom edge of the apron.
Once again, use 2½-inch (6.35-centimeter) screws and wood glue.
Secure the arm rests on top.
Make sure that the back end of the arm rest is level with the front end.
Use a level to make sure that the arm rests are flat.
Secure them with 2½-inch (6.35-centimeter) screws and wood glue.
Cut the slats.
You will need six boards that at 72 inches (182.88 centimeters) long.
Each board needs to be 6 inches (15.24 centimeters) wide and 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) thick.
Attach two slats to the back rest.
Position the slats above and below the arm rests.
The top of the bottom slat should be flush with the bottom of the arm rest.
Use 2-inch (5.08-centimeter) finish nails and wood glue.
Add the seat slats.
Attach the remaining four slats to the support joists.
Leave ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) gaps between them.
The first slat should be flush to the arm fronts.
The back slat should be flush to the back supports.
Use 2-inch (5.08-centimeter) finish nails and wood glue.
Painting and Hanging the Swing Smooth out the surface of the wood, if needed.
Fill in any holes using wood filler.
Let the filler dry, then sand it smooth with 120 grit sandpaper—be sure that you sand with the wood grain, not against it.
Wipe away any dust using a damp cloth.
If you will be painting your swing, it would be a good idea to apply some primer.
Paint or stain the swing.
If you wish to preserve the natural texture of the wood, apply a wood stain.
If you wish to give it a solid color, paint it with a durable, outdoor quality paint.
Apply the paint or stain according to the directions on the can, as each product will be a little different.
You may need more than one coat of paint.
Be sure to let the previous coat dry before applying the next one.
Seal the swing.
Choose a waterproof, outdoor quality varnish.
Apply three coats to your swing.
Allow each coat to dry before applying the next one.
Whether you use a matte, satin, or glossy finish is entirely up to you.
Sealing is important, even if the paint you use is labeled as waterproof.
Attach eye bolts to sides of support jousts, right between the arm front and back rest.
Drill the hole first, all the way through the joust.
Place a washer over the hole, then a nut.
Twist in the eye bolt, all the way through the board.
Place another washer over the end of the bolt on the other side of the beam.
Lastly, twist on the nut.
Make sure that the looped part of the bolt is oriented vertically.
When you look at the swing straight on from the front, it should be shaped like a "O".
Feed the rope through both hooks and tie.
Cut two long pieces of study rope.
Feed your first rope through both hooks on the left side.
Feed your second rope through both hooks on the right side.
Tie the ends together into a sturdy knot on each side.
The rope needs to have a 200-pound (90.72-kilo) weight capacity.
Attach the swing to a sturdy branch or rafter.
Make sure that whatever you are hanging the swing from can support the weight.
If you are hanging the swing from a set of rafters, use eye screws or heavy duty swing hangers.
If the swing is still too tippy after you hang it, add one more set of eye bolts and ropes  to the backrest.
For more comfort, hang it at a slight backward angle, about five degrees.
